column2: US Dollar   The United States dollar (USD) is the official currency of the United States and several of its territories. It is the world’s primary reserve currency and widely used in international trade and finance.

column3: The Canadian dollar (CAD) is the official currency of Canada. It is often called the "loonie" and is one of the world’s most traded currencies.
The Mexican peso (MXN) is the official currency of Mexico. It is one of the most traded currencies from Latin America.
The Brazilian real (BRL) is the official currency of Brazil. It is named after the Portuguese word for "royal" and is the most used currency in South America.
The Argentine peso (ARS) is the official currency of Argentina. It has experienced high inflation and several redenominations.
The Chilean peso (CLP) is the official currency of Chile. It is symbolized by $ and widely used across the nation.
The Colombian peso (COP) is the official currency of Colombia. It has been in use since 1810.
The Peruvian sol (PEN) is the official currency of Peru. It replaced the inti in 1991 and is known for relative stability.
The Uruguayan peso (UYU) is the official currency of Uruguay. It is subdivided into 100 centésimos.
The Paraguayan guaraní (PYG) is the official currency of Paraguay. It is one of the oldest currencies in continuous use in South America.
The Boliviano (BOB) is the official currency of Bolivia. It replaced the peso boliviano in 1987.
The Venezuelan bolívar (VES) is the official currency of Venezuela. It has undergone multiple redenominations due to hyperinflation.
The Dominican peso (DOP) is the official currency of the Dominican Republic. It is symbolized by RD$ and has been in circulation since 1947.
The Costa Rican colón (CRC) is the official currency of Costa Rica. It is named after Christopher Columbus ("Cristóbal Colón" in Spanish).
The Guatemalan quetzal (GTQ) is the official currency of Guatemala. It is named after the national bird, the resplendent quetzal.
The Honduran lempira (HNL) is the official currency of Honduras. It is named after the indigenous leader Lempira.
The Nicaraguan córdoba (NIO) is the official currency of Nicaragua. It is named after the Spanish conquistador Francisco Hernández de Córdoba.
The Panamanian balboa (PAB) is the official currency of Panama. It is pegged to the US dollar and circulates alongside it.
The Barbados dollar (BBD) is the official currency of Barbados. It is pegged to the US dollar at 2:1.
The Trinidad and Tobago dollar (TTD) is the official currency of Trinidad and Tobago. It is denoted by TT$.
The Jamaican dollar (JMD) is the official currency of Jamaica. It replaced the Jamaican pound in 1969.
The Bahamian dollar (BSD) is the official currency of the Bahamas. It is pegged 1:1 to the US dollar.
The Haitian gourde (HTG) is the official currency of Haiti. It replaced the Haitian livre in 1813.
The Belize dollar (BZD) is the official currency of Belize. It is pegged to the US dollar at 2:1.
The Surinamese dollar (SRD) is the official currency of Suriname. It replaced the Surinamese guilder in 2004.
The Guyanese dollar (GYD) is the official currency of Guyana. It has been in use since 1839.
The euro (EUR) is the official currency of the eurozone, used by 20 European Union member states. It is the second-most traded currency worldwide after the US dollar.
The pound sterling (GBP) is the official currency of the United Kingdom. It is the world’s oldest currency still in use and one of the most traded globally.
The Swiss franc (CHF) is the official currency of Switzerland and Liechtenstein. It is regarded as a stable, safe-haven currency.
The Swedish krona (SEK) is the official currency of Sweden. It was introduced in 1873 and is subdivided into 100 öre.
The Norwegian krone (NOK) is the official currency of Norway. It is heavily influenced by the country’s oil-based economy.
The Danish krone (DKK) is the official currency of Denmark, Greenland, and the Faroe Islands. It is pegged to the euro within the ERM II system.
The Polish złoty (PLN) is the official currency of Poland. It is subdivided into 100 grosz and has been relatively stable since the 1990s.
The Czech koruna (CZK) is the official currency of Czechia. Although an EU member, the country has not adopted the euro.
The Hungarian forint (HUF) is the official currency of Hungary. It has been used since 1946 following post-war hyperinflation.
The Romanian leu (RON) is the official currency of Romania. The current leu was redenominated in 2005.
The Bulgarian lev (BGN) is the official currency of Bulgaria. It is pegged to the euro through a currency board arrangement.
The Serbian dinar (RSD) is the official currency of Serbia. Its origins date back to medieval times.
The Ukrainian hryvnia (UAH) is the official currency of Ukraine. It was introduced in 1996, replacing the karbovanets.
The Belarusian ruble (BYN) is the official currency of Belarus. It has undergone several redenominations due to inflation.
The Turkish lira (TRY) is the official currency of Türkiye. It has experienced significant volatility in recent years.
The Icelandic króna (ISK) is the official currency of Iceland. It has been in use since 1922, following the country’s independence from Denmark.
The Croatian kuna (HRK) was the official currency of Croatia until 2023, when it was replaced by the euro. It is now a legacy currency.
The Albanian lek (ALL) is the official currency of Albania. It has been in circulation since 1926 and is named after Alexander the Great.
The Macedonian denar (MKD) is the official currency of North Macedonia. It replaced the Yugoslav dinar in 1992.
The Moldovan leu (MDL) is the official currency of Moldova. It has been in use since 1993, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
The Bosnia and Herzegovina convertible mark (BAM) is the official currency of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is pegged to the euro at a fixed rate.
The Japanese yen (JPY) is the official currency of Japan. It is one of the most traded currencies worldwide and a major reserve currency.
The Chinese yuan renminbi (CNY) is the official currency of the People’s Republic of China. It is increasingly important in international trade and finance.
The Hong Kong dollar (HKD) is the official currency of Hong Kong SAR. It is pegged to the US dollar within a controlled band.
The New Taiwan dollar (TWD) is the official currency of Taiwan. It replaced the old Taiwan dollar in 1949.
The South Korean won (KRW) is the official currency of South Korea. It was introduced in 1945 after liberation from Japanese rule.
The North Korean won (KPW) is the official currency of North Korea. It is not freely convertible and mainly used domestically.
The Singapore dollar (SGD) is the official currency of Singapore. It is managed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and known for its stability.
The Malaysian ringgit (MYR) is the official currency of Malaysia. It replaced the Malaya and British Borneo dollar in 1967.
The Indonesian rupiah (IDR) is the official currency of Indonesia. It has experienced periods of high inflation since its introduction in 1946.
The Thai baht (THB) is the official currency of Thailand. It has a long history and is one of Southeast Asia’s most traded currencies.
The Vietnamese đồng (VND) is the official currency of Vietnam. It is known for its low value relative to major currencies due to historical inflation.
The Philippine peso (PHP) is the official currency of the Philippines. It uses the symbol ₱ and is subdivided into 100 centavos.
The Australian dollar (AUD) is the official currency of Australia and several Pacific territories. It is one of the world’s major commodity-linked currencies.
The New Zealand dollar (NZD) is the official currency of New Zealand and several Pacific territories. It is symbolized by $ or NZ$.
The Indian rupee (INR) is the official currency of India. It is symbolized by ₹ and widely recognized across South Asia.
The Pakistani rupee (PKR) is the official currency of Pakistan. It was introduced in 1947, following independence from British India.
The Bangladeshi taka (BDT) is the official currency of Bangladesh. It has been in circulation since 1972.
The Sri Lankan rupee (LKR) is the official currency of Sri Lanka. It was introduced in 1872, replacing the Ceylonese pound.
The Nepalese rupee (NPR) is the official currency of Nepal. It is pegged to the Indian rupee.
The Myanmar kyat (MMK) is the official currency of Myanmar. It has undergone several redenominations.
The Mongolian tögrög (MNT) is the official currency of Mongolia. It was introduced in 1925, replacing the Mongolian dollar.
The Kazakhstani tenge (KZT) is the official currency of Kazakhstan. It was introduced in 1993, replacing the Soviet ruble.
The Uzbekistani soʻm (UZS) is the official currency of Uzbekistan. It has been in circulation since 1993.
The Kyrgyzstani som (KGS) is the official currency of Kyrgyzstan. It was introduced in 1993 after independence from the Soviet Union.
The Tajikistani somoni (TJS) is the official currency of Tajikistan. It replaced the Tajikistani ruble in 2000.
The Turkmenistani manat (TMT) is the official currency of Turkmenistan. It was redenominated in 2009.
The Georgian lari (GEL) is the official currency of Georgia. It was introduced in 1995, replacing the kuponi.
The Azerbaijani manat (AZN) is the official currency of Azerbaijan. It has undergone several redenominations since its introduction in 1992.
The Armenian dram (AMD) is the official currency of Armenia. It has been in circulation since 1993.
The Saudi riyal (SAR) is the official currency of Saudi Arabia. It is pegged to the US dollar and subdivided into 100 halalas.
The UAE dirham (AED) is the official currency of the United Arab Emirates. It was introduced in 1973, replacing the Qatar and Dubai riyal.
The Qatari riyal (QAR) is the official currency of Qatar. It is pegged to the US dollar and subdivided into 100 dirhams.
The Kuwaiti dinar (KWD) is the official currency of Kuwait. It is notable for being one of the highest-valued currencies in the world.
The Bahraini dinar (BHD) is the official currency of Bahrain. It has been pegged to the US dollar since the 1980s.
The Omani rial (OMR) is the official currency of Oman. It is among the highest-valued currencies globally.
The Israeli new shekel (ILS) is the official currency of Israel. It is symbolized as ₪ and has been in use since 1985.
The Jordanian dinar (JOD) is the official currency of Jordan. It is pegged to the US dollar and subdivided into 100 piastres.
The Lebanese pound (LBP) is the official currency of Lebanon. It has experienced high inflation in recent years.
The Syrian pound (SYP) is the official currency of Syria. It has been in circulation since 1919.
The Yemeni rial (YER) is the official currency of Yemen. It replaced the North Yemeni rial and South Yemeni dinar in the 1990s.
The Iraqi dinar (IQD) is the official currency of Iraq. It replaced the Indian rupee in 1932.
The Iranian rial (IRR) is the official currency of Iran. It has faced persistent devaluation and inflation.
The Egyptian pound (EGP) is the official currency of Egypt. It was introduced in 1834 and is subdivided into 100 piastres.
The Moroccan dirham (MAD) is the official currency of Morocco. It is issued by Bank Al-Maghrib, the central bank of Morocco.
The Algerian dinar (DZD) is the official currency of Algeria. It replaced the Algerian new franc in 1964.
The Tunisian dinar (TND) is the official currency of Tunisia. It is subdivided into 1000 millimes.
The Libyan dinar (LYD) is the official currency of Libya. It replaced the pound in 1971.
The South African rand (ZAR) is the official currency of South Africa. It is also accepted in some neighboring countries.
The Nigerian naira (NGN) is the official currency of Nigeria. It replaced the Nigerian pound in 1973.
The Kenyan shilling (KES) is the official currency of Kenya. It has been in circulation since 1966.
The Tanzanian shilling (TZS) is the official currency of Tanzania. It replaced the East African shilling in 1966.
The Ugandan shilling (UGX) is the official currency of Uganda. It has been in use since 1966.
The Ethiopian birr (ETB) is the official currency of Ethiopia. It has been used since the 19th century in various forms.
The Ghanaian cedi (GHS) is the official currency of Ghana. The current cedi was introduced in 2007 after redenomination.
The West African CFA franc (XOF) is used by 8 West African countries in the WAEMU. It is guaranteed by the French Treasury and pegged to the euro.
The Central African CFA franc (XAF) is used by 6 Central African countries in the CEMAC bloc. It is pegged to the euro.
The CFP franc (XPF) is used in French overseas collectivities in the Pacific. It is pegged to the euro.
The Mauritian rupee (MUR) is the official currency of Mauritius. It was introduced in 1876.
The Mozambican metical (MZN) is the official currency of Mozambique. It replaced the escudo in 1980.
The Angolan kwanza (AOA) is the official currency of Angola. It has been redenominated several times since 1977.
The Zambian kwacha (ZMW) is the official currency of Zambia. It was introduced in 1968 and redenominated in 2013.
The Botswana pula (BWP) is the official currency of Botswana. It is considered one of Africa’s strongest currencies.
The Namibian dollar (NAD) is the official currency of Namibia. It is pegged to and interchangeable with the South African rand.
The Cape Verde escudo (CVE) is the official currency of Cabo Verde. It is pegged to the euro.
The Rwandan franc (RWF) is the official currency of Rwanda. It has been used since 1964.
The Burundian franc (BIF) is the official currency of Burundi. It has been in circulation since 1964.
The Djiboutian franc (DJF) is the official currency of Djibouti. It is pegged to the US dollar.
The Somali shilling (SOS) is the official currency of Somalia. Despite instability, it remains in use in parts of the country.
The Swazi lilangeni (SZL) is the official currency of Eswatini. It is pegged to the South African rand.
The Lesotho loti (LSL) is the official currency of Lesotho. It is pegged to the South African rand.
The South Sudanese pound (SSP) is the official currency of South Sudan. It was introduced in 2011 after independence.
The São Tomé and Príncipe dobra (STN) is the official currency of São Tomé and Príncipe. It was redenominated in 2018.
The Sierra Leonean leone (SLE) is the official currency of Sierra Leone. It was redenominated in 2022.
The gold (XAU) code represents one troy ounce of gold. It is used in international commodities trading and financial markets.
The silver (XAG) code represents one troy ounce of silver. It is used in precious metals trading.
The platinum (XPT) code represents one troy ounce of platinum. It is used in global markets for metals.
The palladium (XPD) code represents one troy ounce of palladium. It is used in commodities trading and investment.
The Special Drawing Rights (XDR) is an international reserve asset created by the IMF. Its value is based on a basket of major world currencies.
The ADB unit of account (XUA) is used by the African Development Bank for internal accounting and reporting.
The SUCRE (XSU) is a regional virtual currency used by some members of the ALBA alliance in Latin America. It is a unit of account for trade settlement.
The European Unit of Account 17 (XBD) is a bond market unit used in special financial instruments. It is not a circulating currency.
The European Unit of Account 9 (XBC) is a financial unit used in bond markets. It is not in public circulation.
The European Monetary Unit (XBB) is a composite unit used in European bond markets prior to the euro. It remains as a funds code.
The European Composite Unit (XBA), also known as EURCO, is a basket unit used in bond markets. It has no physical form.
The East Caribbean dollar (XCD) is the official currency of eight Eastern Caribbean countries. It is pegged to the US dollar.
The West African CFA franc (XOF) is used by 8 countries in the WAEMU bloc. It is pegged to the euro and guaranteed by the French Treasury.
The Central African CFA franc (XAF) is used by 6 countries in the CEMAC bloc. It is pegged to the euro and guaranteed by the French Treasury.
The CFP franc (XPF) is used in French overseas collectivities in the Pacific. It is pegged to the euro and issued by the IEOM.
The XTS code is reserved for testing purposes in systems that require a valid ISO 4217 code. It is not a real currency.
The XXX code is used to denote “no currency” in transactions. It appears in systems when no actual currency is applicable.
The US dollar next day (USN) is a funds code used for US dollar transactions settling the following day. It is not a circulating currency.
The Mexican unidad de inversión (MXV) is an indexed unit of account used in Mexico. It is adjusted for inflation, not a circulating currency.
The Unidad de Valor Real (COU) is a Colombian unit of account tied to inflation. It is used for financial contracts.
The Unidad de Fomento (CLF) is a Chilean inflation-indexed unit of account. It is widely used for mortgages and contracts, not daily cash use.
The WIR euro (CHE) is a complementary currency used in the Swiss WIR economic circle. It is not a circulating national currency.
The WIR franc (CHW) is a complementary currency used in Switzerland’s WIR system. It is used alongside the Swiss franc in business transactions.
The Venezuelan digital bolívar (VED) is a central bank digital currency version of the bolívar. It is part of Venezuela’s monetary system.
